summary: 저명한 수학자 테렌스 타오가 현재 AI 수준을 AGI가 아닌 '인공 일반 영리함(AGC)'으로 정의했다. 그는 AI가 진정한 지능보다는 훈련 데이터에 기반한 임기응변식 해결책을 제시한다고 주장했다.
text: Matthias is the co-founder and publisher of THE DECODER, exploring how AI is fundamentally changing the relationship between humans and computers. Renowned mathematician Terence Tao has proposed a new way to think about AI capabilities. On Mastodon, Tao questions whether true "artificial general intelligence" (AGI) is actually achievable with current AI tools. His alternative: "artificial general cleverness" (AGC). Ad According to Tao, "general cleverness" means the ability to solve complex problems using partly improvised methods. These solutions might be random, rely on raw computing power, or draw from training data. That makes them something other than true "intelligence," but they can still succeed at many tasks, especially when strict testing procedures filter out incorrect results, he says. "This results in the somewhat unintuitive combination of a technology that can be very useful and impressive, while simultaneously being fundamentally unsatisfying and disappointing." Terence Tao In humans, cleverness and intelligence are linked, but in AI they're decoupled, Tao argues. The mathematician has recently spoken positively about how AI has sped up his own work. Ad
title: Terence Tao proposes "artificial general cleverness" as a more honest label for what AI actually does
